quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Tuples[/h1]

[b]Tuples [/b]are very similar to lists, except that they are immutable (they cannot be changed). 
Also, they are created using [b]parentheses[/b], rather than square brackets. 
[b]Example:[/b][code format="py" ]words = [b]([/b]"spam", "eggs", "sausages",[b])[/b][/code]
You can access the values in the tuple with their index, just as you did with lists:[code format="py" codeId="365"]print(words[0])[/code]
Trying to reassign a value in a tuple causes a TypeError. [code format="py" codeId="366"]words[1] = "cheese"[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment
>>>[/code]
[note]Like lists and dictionaries, tuples can be nested within each other.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
tuple = (1, (1, 2, 3))
print(tuple[1])
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Tuples[/h1]

Tuples can be created without the parentheses, by just separating the values with commas.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="367"]my_tuple = "one", "two", "three"
print(my_tuple[0])[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
one
>>>[/code]
An empty tuple is created using an empty parenthesis pair.[code format="py" ]tpl = ()[/code]
[note]Tuples are faster than lists, but they cannot be changed.[/note]
